There's still a chance - but it would need "flawless execution" in December by Tesla, who underwhelmed during October and November. http://insideevs.com/november-2016-plug-electric-vehicle-sales-report-card/
"Tesla announced that all new vehicles were now coming equipped with the functionality as of mid-October production…but they didn’t say how fast that production was happening, or how long it was going to take those vehicles to get to customers. Hint: it was not fast. Some Tesla customers who had expected cars in late September, have seen deliveries slip not only past October, but now November because of the chaos that appears to be the new hardware. Ultimately, Tesla US-bound production of the Model S did get decently underway with some volume by mid-November according to our sources, but apparently the fully self-driving hardware (at least in the early days) have extended the average wait time until delivery (call it extended QC if you like)…because not many got out before the month closed. That said, and for those who might are inclined to be concerned with quarterly sales, production at Tesla seems to be now underway at a very high clip and Tesla is still sitting on a virtual mountain of produced/in production customer ordered cars, that are just about to find a home in December. Does this mean Tesla will hit its Q4/full year estimate?  We can’t say that for sure as the company has definitely backed itself into a corner with AP 2.0.  The company will certainly have an exceptional December, but will need flawless execution throughout the month (something we have yet to see in Q4) to have a shot at those ~25,000 Q4 deliveries."

In order to exceed 80,000 deliveries in 2016 Tesla only needs to exceed its 2nd half guidance of 50,000 cars by 3,210. That implies Q4 deliveries of 28,710, which would be an increase of about 17% from Q3. In light of recent production and delivery growth trends that seems achievable. Tesla has undershot its guidance on a YTD 2016 basis, and in order to maintain credibility it is likely that the company is sandbagging its 2nd half guidance of 50,000 deliveries. Bottom line, I see better than even odds that Tesla will deliver more than 80,000 cars for the full year.

November estimated numbers for American market are out at InsideEVs [1] and they don't look great. Although the numbers at [1] are estimated American sales, we can use them, and our knowledge of actual global deliveries [2,3,4], to extrapolate to global deliveries. In Q1 Tesla reported 14,820 global deliveries, while InsideEVs reported 8,790 American sales; a ratio of ~1.69. In Q2 Tesla reported 14,370 global deliveries, while InsideEVs reported 10,240 American sales; a ratio of ~1.4. In Q3 Tesla reported 24,500 global deliveries, while InsideEVs reported 14,939 American sales; a ratio of ~1.64. Currently, InsideEVs reports that American sales Jan-Nov were 37,919. This suggests between 53,087 and 64,083 global deliveries Jan-Nov (using ratios of 1.4 and 1.69. There is simply no chance that ~16,000 global deliveries would be made in December. Even if we go optimistic and assume that Q4 enjoys a "global deliveries : American sales" ratio of 2, we'd still need over 13,000 American sales to indicate that Tesla was on track to reach 80,000 global deliveries. We have under 4,000 so far, meaning December would need to see "over 9,000" American sales. Completely unprecedented, best month so far (Sep 2016) had 7,550, and that was under Musk's intense pressure to make Q3 profitable, with rumors of substantial discounts. Downgrading to 0%. Car deliveries and y-o-y growth rates: 
Q1 - 14,820 (48%)
Q2 - 14,370 (25%)
Q3 - 24,500 (112%)
Q4 required for 80,000 - 26,310 (51%) This is a required 51% y-o-y growth rate in Q4. Average of each quarterly y-o-y rate back to Q1 14 is 53% with 24% standard deviation. This implies slightly better than 50% chance. Another way of thinking about this - looking at Q-o-Q growth rates, historically Q2 and Q4 have shown strong growth while Q1 and Q3 have been broadly flat q-o-q. If i average the Q2 and Q3 2016 numbers (assume Q2 was depressed due to backlog and this came through in Q3, bumping it up) this would imply c. 19,400 in each of Q2 and Q3 ... and hence the Q4 required figure of a bit over 26,000 would imply a required 35% q-o-q growth on Q3. The average Q4 q-o-q growth rate has been 34% with 15% stdev. This implies a very slightly less than 50% chance.  Taking the above two statistical approaches together I therefore get to a 50% chance (one slightly more likely, one slightly less).  Finally, the Q3 2016 release stated "We expect Q4 deliveries and production to be at or slightly above Q3". The required 26,310 is 7% above the reported Q3 figure - to me this is more than "slightly above", that is a decent beat. I therefore reduce the likelihood by 5% based on this semantic reason (only small reduction as may just be a case of underpromise / overdeliver). I therefore assess probability of reaching 80,000 at 45%.

Updating from 30%. Tesla had a strong Q3 with 24,500 deliveries [1], bringing total 2016 sales to 53,722. This leaves 26,278 deliveries to go. This is more than delivered in any quarter before, but the trend from 2014 and 2015 is Q4 being the biggest quarter of the year by roughly 20%. Thus, it seems safe to predict that Q4 2016 will see more than 24,500 deliveries, or even more than 24,500 + 20% = 29,400. People have noted that the Q3 number includes 5,150 deliveries from the end of Q2, meaning only 19,350 were "true" Q3 deliveries. Sure, but there are 5,500 in transit now, so we'd only need 26,278 - 5,500 = 20,778 "true" Q4 deliveries. That's a very small increase from "true" Q3 deliveries. According to a source I can't find right now, rate of production increased throughout Q3 reached just shy of 2000 at the very end. At 2000 cars / week they would produce a further 26,000 cars in Q4. I don't have any concrete ideas about how they could fail. In very abstract terms, if they used some expendable resource to achieve this remarkable Q3 result, they could be out of this resource for Q4. I don't know what that resource would be. Or, there could be yet another supply chain mishap like has happened in the past. Overall I feel like the chances of 80k cars in 2016 are at least better than even, possibly quite a lot better. But Tesla doesn't release monthly sales so this might well be the last chance to update the forecast based on solid info, so I will play it safe and call it 60%. [1] http://fortune.com/2016/10/02/tesla-backs-2016-target/

In February, Tesla guided for between 80,000 to 90,000 deliveries this year. When it announced its Q2 delivery numbers though, it stated:
"In total, Tesla expects to produce and deliver about 50,000 vehicles during the second half of 2016, approximately equal to all of 2015".

"Production and demand are on track to support deliveries of approximately 50,000 new Model S and Model X vehicles during the second half of 2016."

Per Tesla, Q2 _delivered_ 14,370 vehicles (http://ir.tesla.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=978031).  Combined with Q1, Tesla has delivered 29,190 vehicles this year.  To hit their 80000 target, they would need an average of 25405 vehicles delivered p/qtr; or a +54% increase YOY for Q3 and +31% increase for Q4 YOY. For Q3:
Tesla states that about 5,150 vehicles constructed in Q2 were not delivered and would be delivered in Q3.  I applied that number to Q3 projections; first using average of Q1 & Q2 and then applying the YOY Q3 growth from '14 to '15 (32.9%) to extrapolate Q3 16 numbers.
 * Adding those 5,150 vehicles to the average for first 2 quarters brings Q3 in at 19,745 (or about 5660 shy of the min).
 * Extrapolating Q3 '16 numbers based on '15 by applying 32.9% growth gets us 15,390 units.  Add the 5150 overflow from Q2 and you get 20,540 (or about 4865 shy). For Q4:
Lets assume that they will have the same Q4 growth this year as they did the previous.  See below for details, but they had 43.7% growth in Q4 between '14 and '15.  Given that growth, Q4 '16 numbers would come in at 26,217... or about 812 over the min amount.  Which means that  somewhere between Quarters 3 & 4, Tesla is going to have to find an add'l +20% growth _above_ their typical 30% to 45% quarterly growth year-over-year. Color me skeptical.

This is mostly guess work from stats about the place. CAUTION, CONTAINS ASSUMPTIONS OF NORMALITY, HAND-WAVING. If you look at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Global_sales_Tesla_Model_S_by_quarter.png you can see that Q4 appears to be a relatively good predictor of the next 3 quarters. If we accept Tesla's statement that the poor Q1 performance has been "solved," we can start playing with the (scant) sales data. If we set the expected quarterly volume at 19k, then the overall expected sales is ~74k. This is 12k + 2* 19k + 1.15 * 19K, which covers Q1, Q2, Q3, and the expected Q4 "bump" in the graph above. This is pretty close to 80, but still falls short with p>50%. We must therefore move our prediction to less than 50%. Assuming the std. deviation from my last forecast, about 10K either side, and applying a rough-and-ready z-test, we see that P(X >= 80) = 28.77%. This is a huge swing, so we moderate it with the previous forecast. Simply taking the mid-point gives 46%.

As many commenters like @mparrault have observed, actual delivered units have consistently trailed slightly behind projections. Tesla seems to be aware of this, hence the 'padding' they've built into their projections for 2016.  On top of that, it's going to be challenging to scale up their current operations from 50K delivered cars in 2015 to 80K in 2016. That would be mean achieving a 60% year-over-year increase in deliveries over the previous year--which is significantly higher than recent YoY growth rates (+56% for 2014-2015, +45% for 2013-2014). No doubt demand is there, but can Tesla meet fulfillment expectations at this aggressive pace--especially with recent C-suite departures? Unlikely.

Tesla results. They repeatedly affirmed their comfort around their guidance of 80-90, but the call and shareholder letter (http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/ABEA-4CW8X0/1982505979x0x889927/27EE2FDA-9C77-4D6A-8CEE-E8DFE45227BA/Q1_2016_Tesla_Shareholder_Letter.pdf), did reveal some interesting details.
There production numbers and delivery numbers look something like this: Q1 production 15,510 deliveries 14,820
Q2 production 20,000 deliveries 17,000 ("Due to a large number of vehicles in transit to customers in Europe and Asia at end of quarter")
Q3 production 26,000 deliveries 25,020 assuming 82% delivery lag (and 3700 units from previous quarter)
Q4 production 26,000 deliveries 26,000 assuming 82% delivery lag (and 4680 units from previous quarter) So a total delivery for the year of 82,840 units. This estimate does not include any more production delays, but nor does it include "production increases planned for the back half of 2016". It is bang inside my initial forecast of delivery capacity of 80-85k, despite missing my Q2 forecast by 3-4k. And therein lies the problem, they are using production increases to explain away delivery failures, and whilst I have no reason to doubt them (and the SEC would not look kindly on them deliberately misleading investors on production numbers rather than just guidance), it does introduce a bigger element of doubt and risk of failure, so I will drop my forecast by 12%.

Tesla's initial estimate was 80-90k so they must have felt they would get extra capacity in H2 (why not announce it if it was going to be earlier). To reach 90k it would mean an extra 87pw, so lets round it up to 100pw. This assumes they would have never made an estimate that they knew they couldn't reach under any circumstances (note I am using deliveries as a proxy for production here). Therefore assuming no production issues at all we get the following: Q1 14,820 (using deliveries as a proxy for production)
Q2 22,750
Q3 24,050
Q4 24,050 For a total of 85,670 as a maximum.  However, that assumes production increases come as early as possible. If we were to move them by a month into their respective quarters we would get 84,270, ie still a lot of room. Lets take 85k as a best case. If we do worst case scenario (still assuming no production issues) ie 250pw increase only comes at end of q2 and no q3 or q4 increase we get 79,820. So lets take 80k as a worst case. So my initial estimate is Tesla could produce 80-85k, however I think they could do better in terms of deliveries as if you take Q4 15 delivery numbers for Model S they were 17,192, or about 300pw above production, and according to their press release (http://ir.teslamotors.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=963460) there was production that was not delivered (and here again I am making an assumption that they mentioned this because it was more material than normal). If we give them  just over a week of equivalent production in terms of deliveries (2000), which should be conservative, it results in a potential delivery range of 82-87k, again assuming no further production issues. The production issues were clearly material enough that Tesla felt the need to put out a special explanation (they were 1,180 below guidance). If we repeat that same miss for 2 out of the 3 remaining quarters (but reduce the shortfall by 1000 given the conservative nature of scenario), we would get an overall range of 80-85k. So the ability to supply more that 80k looks safe, turning to the demand side, we have the following information: From Tesla: "New Model S orders grew over 35% year on year in Q4 [2015], with growth in all regions" From Teslamotorclub.com 23apr16 (a site where "fans" log their orders for Teslas, with all the bias that comes with that): "About 50 more Model S are being ordered per day, every day, than the previous quarter and at a current historical high rate." I am not sure how much weight to place on this, but amongst fans it is clear that the Model 3 announcement has not cannabalised the demand for Model S - which was the concern. From above press release "Q1 orders exceeded Q1 deliveries by a wide margin, with Q1 Model S orders being 45% higher than Q1 last year" Unfortunately, it is harder to get information on Model X orders beyond hype/hearsay, but extrapolating from the fact that delivery times are longer for the Model X I will assume that demand is comparable to that of Model S, the latter was always more at risk from Model 3. Q2 deliveries should indicate whether that assumption is valid. Taking all of the above it seems that both in terms of supply and demand there is say an 84% chance of Tesla beating 80,000 deliveries (100% - 10% for random unexpected event, and -6% as analysis depends mainly on Tesla, rather than independent, releases). I will know I am wrong if Q2 deliveries aren't above 21,500, or if there is some special announcement at their results on May 4th.
I'm going to go with yeah, probably. The company missed goals in its early years, but as it matures, I think Tesla will be more likely to be on target.

Like @mparrault 's (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/186413) and @Tinned_Tuna 's (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/186709) comments, I'm basing my prediction off of Tesla's historical prediction accuracy. My one minor change is using their low estimate of 80k as their prediction. The reason is that they used a range for the their prediction once before, in August 2015, when they revised their prior estimate of 55k to 50k-55k (http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2015/08/05/tesla-teeters-after-lowering-guidance/). They ended up squeaking past this revised mark, leading me to believe that their true estimate was that lower benchmark, allowing them to say that they hit their revised mark. Using a range makes marketing sense, as they can say at the end of the year that they reached their target by breaking 80k, but still claim to expect to sell up to 90k, a more impressive number. Thus, using an estimate of 80k, average actual delivery of -1.89%, SD of 12.03%, and a (strong) assumption of normalcy, the probability of breaking 80k is 44%. Their Q1 update saw them hit 14.8k deliveries, missing their Q1 target of 16k, but still sticking with their 80k-90k prediction. I don't think it changes much, so I'll stick with my 44%.

Last year Tesla expected to deliver 50k - 55k cars and actually delivered 50.5k [1], so just over the low end. This year it expects to deliver 80k - 90k so initially I'd expect them to be over the low end as well. I think the number of Model 3 orders surprised everyone, including Tesla, so my guess is they find themselves with more cash on hand than expected --- $1000 for each of 400k orders, that's $400M, pretty substantial. Another thing that springs to mind: Tesla made its 2015 sales prediction in 2014. In 2015, gas prices fell and stayed substantially below 2014 levels [2]. One might think this would drive down demand for electric cars, but they still met their predicted sales. As is well-known, the price of oil is on the rise again [3], so one might expect gas prices to help this year, rather than hinder like last year. In other words, the prediction seems very realistic to me. How could Tesla fail to meet its delivery target? Fewer people might buy than expected; there might some logistical problem; some occurrence (accident?) in the factories that delays production; some problem with the current cars that diverts effort towards fixing it; some lawsuit? I don't know. If I assign 10% chance to the few-buyers option, and 5% probabilities to each of these other obstacles, I come away with a 30% chance of failure. So let's call it a 70%. Assuming those will be rolled out at constant rate over course of 2016 let's call it they will have an average of 261 stores over course of year.  Thus, in order to achieve 60% vehicle sales growth rate, they would have to increase sales per store 35% derived as follows:
221*x=50,000 -> x=226 sales/store/yr
261*(x+y)=80,000 -> y=80.5 increase in sales/store/yr
80.5/226 = 35% increase in sales per store An interesting analysis would be to count number of retail locations & sales in prior years to determine growth rate of sales per store. The Palo Alto, Calif., auto maker’s direct-to-consumer sales are prohibited by law in six states that represent about 18% of the U.S. new-car market. Barring a change of heart by those states, Tesla is preparing to make a federal case out of the direct-sales bans.
The auto maker’s legal staff has been studying a 2013 federal appeals court ruling in New Orleans that determined St. Joseph Abbey could sell monk-made coffins to customers without having a funeral director’s license. The case emerged amid a casket shortage after Hurricane Katrina. The abbey had tried to sell coffins, only to find state laws restricted such sales to those licensed by the Louisiana Board of Funeral Directors.
For now, Tesla is banking on a combination of new legislation, pending dealer applications and other factors to open doors to selling directly in Arizona, Michigan, Texas, Connecticut, Utah and West Virginia. But the company said it is ready to argue in federal court using the coffin case if necessary.

WARNING: THIS COMMENT CONTAINS A STRONG ASSUMPTION OF NORMALITY. CONSUME WITH CARE AND PLENTY OF SALT. The sales figures supplied by @mparrault show that Tesla miss their predictions by an average of -1.89%. Unfortunately, we've only got 3 sales figures to work with, giving us a standard deviation of 12.03%, which is vast. Taking the expected mean of 83.40K, and expected standard deviation of 12.03%, then we work out that 1 standard deviation is pretty close to 10.03K either side. Applying a z-score and looking up from a table gives us P(X < 80) = 0.3669. Therefore, P(X >= 80) = 0.6331. Obviously, this is making the very strong assumption of normality (Ha!) on the basis of 3 samples!! There are probably better estimators of this out there.

I think they have a chance to deliver that many vehicles, but from what I have read they have only delivered 60,000 vehicles to date.  There is an apparent backlog on demand for the vehicles, so the market appears to be there, but news reports indicate previous production delays may be over with the newly build facility in Nevada coming online.  80,000 is probably doable this year, if everything goes according to plan, but so far Tesla has not been able to operate as planned.
Taking Tesla at their word -- initially.

In the first 2 months of 2016 Tesla has sold 3170 cars compared to 2250 in the first 2 months of 2015 giving them about a 33% increase in sales. http://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/ Their prediction for 2016 is based on the 52% increase in yearly sales that they have maintained in the past.  http://bgr.com/2016/01/03/tesla-model-s-sales-2015/
As gas prices drop and mpg rises on new cars, interest in electric cars may drop.  Some states have also phased out or are phasing out incentives that have been offered. 
The X model could help sales, but production is slow and they are always on backlog so it takes months to get a car.  Can they even produce 80,000 in one year?
